Selecting groups of programs

Source: vignettes/selecting_programs.Rmd
selecting_programs.Rmd

In the vignettes illustrating various persistence metrics, the first step is to select the programs to study. We will use the same set of programs in different vignettes, so here we show the details of selecting and labeling those programs.

The programs we are studying are Civil Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Industrial Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering.

Getting started

# packages used
library(midfieldr)
library(dplyr)
library(seplyr)

Select the programs to study

We use cip_filter() to search the cip dataset first for Engineering and then filter the result for Civil, Electrical, Industrial, and Mechanical.

cip_filter(cip, series = "Engineering") %.>%
  cip_filter(., series = c("Civil", "Electrical", "Industrial", "Mechanical")) %.>%
  head(., n = 15L)
#> # A tibble: 15 x 6
#>    cip2  cip2name     cip4  cip4name             cip6  cip6name                 
#>    <chr> <chr>        <chr> <chr>                <chr> <chr>                    
#>  1 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Civil Engineering, Gener~
#>  2 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Geotechnical Engineering 
#>  3 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Structural Engineering   
#>  4 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Transportation and Highw~
#>  5 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Water Resources Engineer~
#>  6 14    Engineering  1408  Civil Engineering    1408~ Civil Engineering, Other 
#>  7 14    Engineering  1410  Electrical, Electro~ 1410~ Electrical, Electronics ~
#>  8 14    Engineering  1410  Electrical, Electro~ 1410~ Laser and Optical Engine~
#>  9 14    Engineering  1410  Electrical, Electro~ 1410~ Telecommunications Engin~
#> 10 14    Engineering  1410  Electrical, Electro~ 1410~ Electrical, Electronics ~
#> 11 14    Engineering  1419  Mechanical Engineer~ 1419~ Mechanical Engineering   
#> 12 14    Engineering  1435  Industrial Engineer~ 1435~ Industrial Engineering   
#> 13 14    Engineering  1441  Electromechanical E~ 1441~ Electromechanical Engine~
#> 14 15    Engineering~ 1502  Civil Engineering T~ 1502~ Civil Engineering Techno~
#> 15 15    Engineering~ 1503  Electrical Engineer~ 1503~ Electrical, Electronic a~

Noting that technology programs are typically not accredited as engineering programs, the results show that the codes we want are 1408 Civil, 1410 Electrical, 1419 Mechanical, and 1435 Industrial. We individually extract these programs.

cve <- cip_filter(cip, series = "^1408")
ele <- cip_filter(cip, series = "^1410")
mce <- cip_filter(cip, series = "^1419")
ise <- cip_filter(cip, series = "^1435")

We will use cip_label() to assign program names to these programs. One possibility is to use the 4-digit program names already available in the data. To view those names:

unique(cve[["cip4name"]])
#> [1] "Civil Engineering"
unique(ele[["cip4name"]])
#> [1] "Electrical, Electronics and Communications Engineering"
unique(mce[["cip4name"]])
#> [1] "Mechanical Engineering"
unique(ise[["cip4name"]])
#> [1] "Industrial Engineering"

Except for Electrical Engineering, the default program names are concise. We use cip_label() to assign default names to three of the programs and a shorter name for Electrical Engineering.

cve <- cip_label(cve, program = "cip4name")
ele <- cip_label(ele, program = "Electrical Engineering")
mce <- cip_label(mce, program = "cip4name")
ise <- cip_label(ise, program = "cip4name")

cip_label() is pipe-compatible, so these lines could have been combined, for example,

cve <- cip_filter(cip, "^1408") %.>%
  cip_label(., "cip4name")

We use bind_rows(), a dplyr function, to bind the individual data frames into one data frame.

program_group <- bind_rows(cve, ele, mce, ise)

Examine the result: there are a total of 12 CIP codes for these programs. We have 7 columns: 6 from the cip dataset and the one program column of labels we added using cip_label().

program_group
#> # A tibble: 12 x 7
#>    cip2  cip2name  cip4  cip4name           cip6  cip6name            program   
#>    <chr> <chr>     <chr> <chr>              <chr> <chr>               <chr>     
#>  1 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Civil Engineering,~ Civil Eng~
#>  2 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Geotechnical Engin~ Civil Eng~
#>  3 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Structural Enginee~ Civil Eng~
#>  4 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Transportation and~ Civil Eng~
#>  5 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Water Resources En~ Civil Eng~
#>  6 14    Engineer~ 1408  Civil Engineering  1408~ Civil Engineering,~ Civil Eng~
#>  7 14    Engineer~ 1410  Electrical, Elect~ 1410~ Electrical, Electr~ Electrica~
#>  8 14    Engineer~ 1410  Electrical, Elect~ 1410~ Laser and Optical ~ Electrica~
#>  9 14    Engineer~ 1410  Electrical, Elect~ 1410~ Telecommunications~ Electrica~
#> 10 14    Engineer~ 1410  Electrical, Elect~ 1410~ Electrical, Electr~ Electrica~
#> 11 14    Engineer~ 1419  Mechanical Engine~ 1419~ Mechanical Enginee~ Mechanica~
#> 12 14    Engineer~ 1435  Industrial Engine~ 1435~ Industrial Enginee~ Industria~

When searching the midfielddata datasets for students in these programs, our search functions use the 6-digit CIP codes in the cip6 variable. To confirm that the search terms are what we expect, we can extract and view the 12 unique codes.

unique(program_group[["cip6"]])
#>  [1] "140801" "140802" "140803" "140804" "140805" "140899" "141001" "141003"
#>  [9] "141004" "141099" "141901" "143501"

For additional information, try the Selecting CIP codes vignette and the help pages by running ?cip_filter and ?cip_label.

Data set: case_program_group

For convenience, this data frame of engineering CIP codes and program names has been bundled with midfieldr to use in vignettes.

To access the data frame, just load midfieldr and assign the data to an object such as program_group.

program_group <- case_program_group %.>%
  glimpse(.)
#> Rows: 12
#> Columns: 7
#> $ cip2     <chr> "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14"...
#> $ cip2name <chr> "Engineering", "Engineering", "Engineering", "Engineering"...
#> $ cip4     <chr> "1408", "1408", "1408", "1408", "1408", "1408", "1410", "1...
#> $ cip4name <chr> "Civil Engineering", "Civil Engineering", "Civil Engineeri...
#> $ cip6     <chr> "140801", "140802", "140803", "140804", "140805", "140899"...
#> $ cip6name <chr> "Civil Engineering, General", "Geotechnical Engineering", ...
#> $ program  <chr> "Civil Engineering", "Civil Engineering", "Civil Engineeri...
